channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Live Updates: 1 Million Flee Ukraine as Russia Bombards Key Cities
item.description: Russian troops were gaining ground in critical parts of the south and threatening to cut off Ukraine’s access to the Black Sea.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Damage from a rocket strike at the main rail station in Kyiv on Thursday.

item.title: In Glitter and Leotards, They Took a Stand: Brazil's Carnival Must Go On
item.description: After Brazil’s biggest party was effectively canceled for the second straight year, a group of artists rallied to play on despite police orders.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas
item.media:credit: Dado Galdieri for The New York Times
item.media:description: Musicians and revelers crowding a downtown street in Rio de Janeiro on Monday.

item.title: Hundreds Held After New Zealand-Led Investigation Into Images of Child Abuse
item.description: An international collaboration resulted in the rescue of dozens of children and exposed a secret global network used to share material on sexual abuse.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Interpol’s headquarters in Lyon, France. The investigation began in New Zealand but brought together security agencies in various countries, including Interpol.

item.title: Putin’s War to Bring Ukraine to Heel Unites Eastern Europe in Alarm
item.description: Many countries fear that the Russian leader’s efforts to turn back the clock and reclaim a sphere of influence lost at the end of the Cold War could spell disaster for them.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: Maciek Nabrdalik for The New York Times
item.media:description: Mieczyslaw Zuk stands in a former military bunker in Podborsko, Poland, that once housed Soviet nuclear weapons, last month. It is now The Museum of Cold War, where he works as a guide.

item.title: Here's How the Russia-Ukraine War Is Evolving
item.description: Europe’s largest ground war since World War II is moving toward an increasingly brutal phase.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora and Mike Ives
item.media:description: Ukrainian emergency services officers in Kharkiv trying to remove the body of a rocket they said had been fired by Russian forces on Friday.

item.title: NATO Countries Pour Weapons Into Ukraine, Risking Conflict With Russia
item.description: Brussels is proud to be providing military aid, but Moscow may see it as a dangerous intervention.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:credit: Lithuanian Ministry of Defense, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Lithuanian forces loading Stinger anti-aircraft systems and body armor bound for Ukraine, in a photograph provided by Lithuania’s defense ministry.

item.title: 15,000 Are Sheltering in Kyiv’s Subway
item.description: People sleep three or four to a mattress and plastic food bags litter the scene, while mothers search endlessly on their phones for news of the war.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer and Lynsey Addario
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times

item.title: Ukrainians Build Defenses and Wait for Attacks In Odessa
item.description: Residents of Odessa, Ukraine’s critical port on the Black Sea, are bracing as Russian naval and ground forces approach. “Every day they make it seem like today is the day,” the mayor said.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz
item.media:description: Steel barricades, used to obstruct tanks and other armored vehicles, being welded on Tuesday in Odessa, Ukraine.

item.title: As Cases Skyrocket, New Zealand Finally Faces Its Covid Reckoning
item.description: New Zealanders are anxious as they learn to live with the pandemic-related risk that has been a fact of life elsewhere for two years.
item.dc:creator: Pete McKenzie
item.media:description: Health workers handing out rapid antigen tests in Auckland, New Zealand, last month. The Omicron variant is driving a wave of infections.

item.title: Maduro Trades Old Guard for Slick Technocrats to Keep Power
item.description: A new generation of cosmopolitan Venezuelan officials has allowed President Nicolás Maduro to halt the economic collapse and remain in power, at the cost of fostering potential future challenges to his rule.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times

item.title: Also at Stake in Ukraine: the Future of Two Orthodox Churches
item.description: The Russian church hopes to reunite with the independent Ukrainian branch under a single patriarch in Moscow that would allow it to control the holiest sites of Orthodoxy in the Slavic world.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Worshippers attending a service at the Kyiv Monastery of the Caves, one of the holiest sites for Eastern Orthodox Christianity in Ukraine and Russia, on Tuesday in Kyiv.

item.title: Taliban Search Operation Echoes Resented U.S. Tactics in Afghanistan
item.description: An intrusive sweep that has spanned several provinces risks alienating Afghans and fueling the insurgency the new government is trying to stop.
item.dc:creator: Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Christina Goldbaum and Najim Rahim
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dozens of Taliban checkpoints have sprung up across Kabul, part of a broad search operation in several provinces.

item.title: Asian Nations' Mixed Reactions to the Ukraine Invasion
item.description: While most American allies in the region have fallen in line, authoritarian governments and those with weaker ties to the West have been more reluctant to act.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee, Emily Schmall and Sameer Yasir
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: The scene after a residential building was hit by missiles in Kyiv, Ukraine, on Friday.

item.title: Hong Kong, Buckling Under Covid, Leaves Its Most Vulnerable in the Cold
item.description: Poor residents have been forced to choose between infecting their families or sleeping outdoors because of cramped living quarters and a lack of isolation facilities.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang
item.media:description: Domestic workers being ordered to leave. The authorities in Hong Kong have targeted domestic workers with heavy fines for flouting social distancing rules.

item.title: Anna Netrebko, Diva With Putin Ties, Is Out at the Metropolitan Opera
item.description: The Met said she would not appear for two seasons, and possibly more, after declining to comply with its demand that she repudiate her public support for Putin.
item.dc:creator: Javier C. Hernández
item.media:description: The soprano Anna Netrebko is “one of the greatest singers in Met history,” the opera company’s general manager said, “but with Putin killing innocent victims in Ukraine there was no way forward.”

item.title: In Ukraine’s Information War, a Blend of Fact and Fiction
item.description: Experts say stories like the Ghost of Kyiv and Snake Island, both of questionable veracity, are propaganda or morale boosters, or perhaps both.
item.dc:creator: Stuart A. Thompson and Davey Alba
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Dnieper River embankment in the Podil neighborhood of Kyiv last Thursday.

item.title: French Volunteers Plan to Head to Ukraine to Join its New Foreign Legion
item.description: And Ukraine is welcoming them and other volunteers with open arms.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:description: A man who said he was looking to volunteer to fight spoke with a staff member of the Ukrainian Embassy in London on Wednesday. Hundreds of Europeans are said to have responded to Ukraine’s call for help.

item.title: Ben Franklin’s Vaccine Lessons
item.description: And the overnight news from Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt

item.title: One week into the war and with cities under siege, a humanitarian crisis looms.
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: Russian forces seize Kherson.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost and Manan Luthra

item.title: Russian Forces Seize Kherson, the First Ukrainian City to Fall
item.description: Russian forces seized the southern city of Kherson and besieged other cities, with casualties and destruction mounting, as Western sanctions tightened their vise grip on Russia’s economy.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz and Richard Pérez-Peña
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Members of the Ukrainian military earlier this month in Kherson. The city fell to Russia on Wednesday.

item.title: How the Coronavirus Steals the Sense of Smell
item.description: The virus does not infect nerve cells that detect odors, researchers have found. Instead, it attacks nearby supporting cells.
item.dc:creator: Roni Caryn Rabin
item.media:credit: Fabio Bucciarelli for The New York Times
item.media:description: A sensory workshop at the Catholic University of Sacred Heart in Piacenza, Italy, organized to help people with long Covid recover their sense of smell, in July.

item.title: Justice Dept. Announces Task Force to Go After Russian Oligarchs
item.description: The task force adds to the raft of actions that Western leaders have taken in recent days in an effort to undercut Vladimir V. Putin and the politically connected elite in Russia.
item.dc:creator: Katie Benner
item.media:description: The creation of the task force reflects the mounting scrutiny cast on Russia’s wealthy elite. The Russian oligarch Roman Abramovich said on Wednesday that he would sell Chelsea, the Premier League soccer team.

item.title: High-Speed Trains Departing Russia for Finland Are Packed
item.description: Once starved for passengers, the trains are now full, and negotiations are underway between state-owned Finnish and Russian rail companies to increase the service.
item.dc:creator: Christina Anderson
item.media:description: An Allegro high-speed train bound for Helsinki at St. Petersburg’s Finlyandsky railway station.

item.title: A War the Kremlin Tried to Disguise Becomes a Hard Reality for Russians
item.description: Moscow posted a death toll from its attack on Ukraine for the first time, and Russians who long avoided politics are now grappling with the fact that their country is fighting a deadly conflict.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Nechepurenko and Anton Troianovski
item.media:description: A Russian tank burning next to an unidentified soldier’s body during a fight with the Ukrainian armed forces in Kharkiv, Ukraine, on Sunday.

item.title: Gold Ingots From 18th-Century Shipwreck Returned to France
item.description: The Chinese ingots, illegally harvested from a French frigate that sank while returning from Nanjing, were seized by U.S. investigators when they were put up for auction in California.
item.dc:creator: Tom Mashberg
item.media:description: A special agent with U.S. Homeland Security Investigations holding two of the five gold ingots that were returned to France.

item.title: Ukrainian Civilian Casualties Rise, but Number Is Uncertain
item.description: As is often the case in war zones, tolls diverged. It was not immediately possible for The New York Times to provide an independent estimate.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:description: The Ukrainian village of Dachne, north of Odessa, on Wednesday, as Russian forces escalated attacks on civilian targets.

item.title: The U.S. extends technology restrictions to Belarus and the Russian oil industry.
item.description: The Biden administration said the measures would degrade the ability to wage war on Ukraine and would prevent Belarus from channeling forbidden goods to Russia.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Russian and Belarusian military personnel during joint military exercises last month. The Biden administration said Belarus had aided Russia’s invasion of Ukraine.

item.title: U.N. General Assembly Approves Resolution Condemning Russia’s Invasion
item.description: The four-page document calls for an immediate halt to the conflict, urges diplomatic negotiations for a peaceful resolution and says Russia’s territorial gain through force will not be recognized.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi

item.title: Ukraine War and U.S. Politics Complicate Climate Change Fight
item.description: Climate change, a central part of Biden’s agenda, was barely mentioned in the State of the Union. And Europe is confronting its heavy reliance on Russian gas.
item.dc:creator: Somini Sengupta and Lisa Friedman
item.media:credit: Valerie Plesch for The New York Times
item.media:description: Supporters of Ukraine outside the White House on Tuesday.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing: Russia Seizes Kherson
item.description: A strategically important city falls.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic
item.media:description: The village of Dachne, just north of Odessa, which was bombed yesterday at midday, killing one person.

item.title: China Asked Russia to Delay Ukraine War Until After Olympics, Biden Officials Say
item.description: A Western intelligence report indicates that Chinese officials had some level of direct knowledge about President Vladimir V. Putin’s war plans or intentions.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong and Julian E. Barnes
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, left, and President Xi Jinping of China meeting last month on the day of the Olympics opening ceremony in Beijing.

item.title: Valery Gergiev and Anna Netrebko's Putin Ties Threaten Their Careers
item.description: The Russian conductor Valery Gergiev and the diva Anna Netrebko have lost engagements because of their ties to Putin, as geopolitics and music collide once again.
item.dc:creator: Zachary Woolfe
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia addressed the audience via video link before Valery Gergiev conducted the Mariinsky Orchestra in the Syrian city of Palmyra in 2016.

item.title: Video: Mayor of Konotop Asks His City Whether They Wish to Fight or Surrender
item.description: The mayor of Konotop, in northeastern Ukraine, said Russian soldiers had told him they would “raze the city to the ground with their artillery.”
item.dc:creator: Dmitriy Khavin, David Botti and Ainara Tiefenthäler

item.title: E.U. Expected to Grant Blanket Protection to Ukrainian Refugees
item.description: Under the measure, which would apply to all Ukrainian nationals, refugees would be granted the right to live, study and work across the 27-member bloc for up to three years.
item.dc:creator: Monika Pronczuk and Dan Bilefsky
item.category: United Nations High Commission for Refugees
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Anna Rogachova 34 embracing her mother Viktoria Tkatchenko 54, on Tuesday after leaving Odessa. Anna is going to Germany, while Viktoria is staying in Moldova.

item.title: Biden for Democracy
item.description: Ukraine took center stage at the State of the Union.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt and Ian Prasad Philbrick
item.media:description: President Biden delivering his state of the union address.

item.title: New Zealand Police Move to End Protest, and Violence Erupts
item.description: Fires and violence at a protest opposing vaccine mandates were a rare sight in a country known for its relative serenity and stability.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: A protester throwing plastic onto a fire as the police moved in to clear a demonstration on the Parliament grounds in Wellington, New Zealand, on Wednesday.

item.title: C.D.C. Updates Contact-Tracing and Case Investigation Guidance
item.description: “The updated guidance is in response to changes in the nature of the pandemic and the increasing availability of new tools to prevent transmission and mitigate illness,” the agency said.
item.dc:creator: Adeel Hassan
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: A public health nurse with the Salt Lake County Health Department in Utah explained contact tracing in 2020.

item.title: Billionaires Battle Over a Hotel and Quality of Life on St. Barts
item.description: A legal feud over a hotel in St. Barts pits development against fragile nature on this tropical Arcadia for the ultrarich. It might also signal a turning point in the hyper-development of the island.
item.dc:creator: Nina Burleigh
item.media:credit: Jean Vallette for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hyper-development is rattling St. Barts. Deluxe yachts pack the harbor in its capital, Gustavia.

item.title: Death of Indian Student in Ukraine Shows Plight of Thousands
item.description: Naveen Shekharappa was killed when he left a bunker in Kharkiv to fetch food, officials and his family members said.
item.dc:creator: Suhasini Raj
item.media:description: A memorial in New Delhi on Tuesday. Naveen Shekharappa, an Indian medical student, was killed when he left a bunker in Kharkiv, Ukraine.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing
item.description: Russia targets civilian areas.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Patrons at a bar in Moscow on Tuesday as President Vladimir V. Putin spoke during a televised meeting with Prime Minister Viktor Orban of Hungary.

item.title: ‘There Will Be a Battle’: A Family Prepares for War in Kyiv
item.description: As the war in Ukraine moves closer to the capital, some families are facing a difficult choice: Stay home or take up arms.
item.dc:creator: Yousur Al-Hlou, Masha Froliak, Mark Boyer and Michael Downey
item.media:credit: Michael Downey for The New York Times

item.title: The Biden administration plans to release a new coronavirus strategy on Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: Sheryl Gay Stolberg
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden has been walking a fine line in addressing the coronavirus pandemic.

item.title: Russia Escalates Attacks on Ukraine as Refugee Numbers Surge
item.description: There was no sign of possible de-escalation on the sixth day of the invasion, as Russia appeared determined to toughen its tactics against a defiant neighbor.
item.dc:creator: Andrew E. Kramer, Valerie Hopkins and Nick Cumming-Bruce
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Marina Shuyeva, 37, visited a monastery in Kyiv on Tuesday to pray for her son and family in Kharkiv.

item.title: Jewish Groups Condemn Strike Near Babyn Yar Holocaust Memorial
item.description: It was not clear what damage was done to the memorial but it is close to a radio and television tower in Kyiv that was hit by a projectile.
item.dc:creator: Nadav Gavrielov
item.category: Babyn Yar Holocaust Memorial Center (Kyiv, Ukraine)
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Mirror Field monument, part of the Babyn Yar Holocaust Memorial Site, in Kyiv, Ukraine, last year.

item.title: Russian Casualties Expose a Potential Flaw in Putin’s Strategy
item.description: Videos and photos show the bodies of soldiers left behind on the battlefield, officials say, and the charred remains of tanks and armored vehicles.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper and Eric Schmitt
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia visiting the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier in Moscow last week. Rising military casualties in Ukraine could seriously erode support for Mr. Putin.

item.title: Many Ukrainian Nuclear Power Reactors No Longer Produce Electricity
item.description: Six of the 15 reactors in the country appear to be offline at the moment, with one site close to Russian troop movements reporting half of its reactors are down.
item.dc:creator: William J. Broad
item.media:description: A photo from 2008 of the Zaporizhzhia nuclear power complex of six reactors in the town of Enerhodar, in eastern Ukraine.

item.title: Ukraine War Sets Off Europe’s Fastest Migration in Decades
item.description: At least 660,000 people, mostly women and children, fled Ukraine in the five days after Russia invaded — the most intense wave of European migration since at least the 1990s.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Refugees on Tuesday at the Ukrainian-Moldovan border.

item.title: How Ukrainians Are Using Social Media to Speak Out About the War
item.description: Ukrainians take to social media, and taboos are tumbling as countries abandon neutrality and people abandon indifference to support their cause.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:description: A protest against Russia’s invasion of Ukraine in Paris on Saturday.

item.title: U.K. Moves to Tighten Laws on Oligarchs. Critics Say It’s Too Late.
item.description: With most of the Western world uniting against Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, Britain is trying to plug loopholes for wealthy Russians to which it has long turned a blind eye.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Tom Jamieson for The New York Times
item.media:description: Evgeny Lebedev, owner of the London Evening Standard and Independent newspapers, in 2014.

item.title: Palestinians Threatened With Eviction Can Stay in Their Homes — for Now
item.description: Israel’s high court stayed the eviction of four Palestinian families from their East Jerusalem homes. The eviction threat had stoked tensions that led to war in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: A protest in the East Jerusalem neighborhood of Sheikh Jarrah last week against the threatened evictions of Palestinian families there.

item.title: Your Wednesday Briefing: A Convoy Nears Kyiv
item.description: Plus the U.S. State of the Union and South Korea’s fight over multiculturalism.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: A satellite image showing part of a 40-mile-long Russian military convoy near Kyiv, Ukraine, on Monday.

item.title: Miles-Long Russian Convoy Outside Kyiv Signals Tactical Shift
item.description: Satellite imagery has shown a Russian military convoy stretching 40 miles on a roadway north of Ukraine’s capital, Kyiv. Experts say it probably indicates a shift to siege tactics.
item.dc:creator: Megan Specia

item.title: Why Joining the E.U. May Not Be Easy for Ukraine
item.description: Russia’s invasion of Ukraine is helping to focus minds in Brussels. But the country has big hurdles to overcome before it can join the E.U., the world’s biggest trading bloc.
item.dc:creator: Dan Bilefsky
item.media:description: Ukraine’s ambassador to Belgium, Mykola Tochytskyi, center, applauded on Tuesday after a video address by the country’s president, Volodymyr Zelensky, during a special plenary session of the European Parliament in Brussels.

item.title: Workers strike in a London Underground already battered by the pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Christine Hauser and Amanda Holpuch
item.media:description: Transport workers in London started the first of two 24-hour strikes planned for this week amid concerns over unfilled posts, pensions and the long-term financing of the rail system.

item.title: Africans Say Ukrainian Authorities Hindered Them From Fleeing
item.description: Africans and other foreigners in Ukraine say border guards made them endure long waits and even beat them, while letting Ukrainians through quickly. Ukraine denied discriminating.
item.dc:creator: Monika Pronczuk and Ruth Maclean
item.media:credit: Mauricio Lima for The New York Times
item.media:description: Foreigners who were living in Ukraine and are now refugees wait for friends to arrive after crossing into Poland in the town of Medyka on Monday.
